section.name: Project File
section.p: A project file is an XML file that describes which tasks to execute, and in which order to execute them in. A project can be broken up into several steps, or targets. A target is simply a list of the tasks that need to be executed to perform the step. A target may also include some dependency information. Myrmidon makes sure that targets are executed in the correct order, so that a target is executed before the targets that depend on it.
The project file format is very similar to the format used in Ant 1. The root element of a project file must be a <project> element. It can take the following attributes:

tr.td: The name of the project file, with the extension removed.
The base directory for the project. The base directory is used to resolve all relative file names used in the project file.
The directory containing the project file.
The name of the default target.
The project file format version that the project is written for.

section.p: A <project> element can contain the following elements, in the order given below:

subsection.name: Project References
subsection.p: Project references allow the project to import, or reference, other projects. A <projectref> element takes the following attributes:

tr.td: The name to use to identify the referenced project.
The path to the project file to reference.

subsection.p: The targets of a referenced project can be used in the depends list of a target in the referencing project, using the syntax project-name->target-name. Here is a simple example:
subsection.source:
<project version="2.0"> <!-- Reference another project --> <projectref name="subproject" location="subproject/build.xml"/>
<!-- Use the "compile" target from the referenced project --> <target name="main" depends="subproject->compile"> .. do some stuff .. </target> </project>

subsection.name: Library Imports
subsection.p: Library imports allow the project to import the tasks and data-types from an antlib. An <import> element takes the following attributes:

tr.td: The name of the library to import. The ext directory of the Myrmidon distribution is searched for a library file with the given name, and an atl extension.
The type of definition to import. Values include task, and data-type.
The name of the type to import.

subsection.p: If the type and name attributes are not provided, the entire contents of the antlib are imported.
The following example import the <my-task> task from the my-tasks antlib.
subsection.source:
<project version="2.0"> <!-- Import task <my-task> from the 'my-tasks' antlib. --> <import library="my-tasks" type="task" name="my-task"/>
<target name="main"> <my-task some-prop=".."/> </target> </project>

subsection.name: Initialization Tasks
subsection.p: Initialisation tasks are run before any of the project's targets are run, and are used to initialise the project. Any task can be used as an initialization task, including <property> and data-type instances. An example:
subsection.source:
<project version="2.0">
<property name="some-property" value="some value"/> <path id="classpath"> <fileset dir="lib"/> </path> <log>Set classpath to ${classpath}</log>
<target name="main"> .. do some stuff .. </target>
</project>

subsection.name: Targets
subsection.p: Targets have a similar format to targets in Ant 1.x, though some of the behaviour is different. A <target> element takes the following attributes:

tr.td: A comma-separated list of targets that this target depends on. This list can contain targets from referenced projects.

section.name: Tasks
section.p: Listed below are some of the current set of tasks. You can find example usages of these tasks in the sample project file src/make/sample.ant.
Sets a property if a particular condition is true. See Conditions for a list of available conditions.
Causes the build to fail.
Conditionally executes a set of tasks.
Loads a set of properties from a file.
Writes a log message.
Sets a property.
Runs a set of tasks, with a provided error and clean-up handler.
Register a type converter. These are used when configuring a task or data-type from attributes.
Register a task or data-type.
Register the contents of an antlib.

section.name: Conditions
section.p: The following conditions are available
Evaluates a set of nested conditions, and AND them together. Evaluation is lazy. An empty <and> condition evaluates to true.
Tests if a particular class or resource is available.
Tests a file against a set of file selectors.
Tests whether a proeprty is set, and not set to 'false'.
Evaluates a set of nested conditions, and OR them together. Evaluation is lazy. An empty <or> evaluates to true.
Tests which operating system the build is running on.
Negates a nested condition.

section.name: File Name Mappers
section.p: The following file name mappers are available:
Applies a set of nested file name mappers to file names.
Maps all file names to a single directory.
Adds a prefix to the front of each file name.
Changes the extension of file names.
